posts.subject: Board development and new features
posts.body:
== Adding new features to the board ==

Hi. I'm currently taking requests to add new features to the zite. Which of the following features would you like to see implemented? Just pick one, give a short justification for it and I'll count your vote. Please consider some features would be easier to implement than others. Estimated difficulty is in parentheses. Current votes in square brackets.

1. Mute button on the catalog (2/10) [0]
2. Ability to hide threads and posts without muting an user (4/10) [0]
3. Ability to store the board on a spare partition with plausible deniability to run it from Tails (8/10) [0]
4. Script to easily create and switch between ZeroID certs (5/10) [0]
5. Research the possibility of setting up a custom CA, which would make it possible to generate certs for every post, basically making everyone anonymous, but it would still be centralized and open to for example DDoS (7/10) [0]
6. Research seed ratio based proof-of-work for posting, which would allow decentralized anonymous posting without additional CPU usage (9/10) [0]
7. Research CPU based proof-of-work for posting, which would mean anonymous decentralized posting but result in higher CPU usage (7/10) [0]
8. Ability to subscribe to other people's blacklists (5/10) [1: usernamesareover]
9. Research ability to fork the board while preserving people's posts (for example, to run your own custom board software without people having to update theirs manually) (6/10) [0]
10. Ability to store people's deleted post and edit histories (4/10) [0]
11. A version of the board's software that doesn't display names by default and doesn't show the option to enable them (2/10) [4: removeboomer, zeronetuser99, 263222931, s5sohmvgm5]
12. CSS to imitate legacy 8chan looks (3/10) [1: mudpeople]
13. Make Millchan faster and less bloated (6/10) [1: taylovedyou]
14. Livestreaming capabilities (6/10) [0]
15. Publicly accessible crowdsourced changelog of the zite's code to easily detect any modifications to it the admin (or whoever gets his private key) might make (2/10) [0]
16. Ability to easily read all posts made by a user (4/10) [0]
17. Proof of concept software to demonstrate ways in which users might be tracked even when switching IDs (5/10) [0]
18. Add statistics to the zite (3/10) [0]
19. Add pinktext support (1/10) [0]
20. Add numbered lists (2/10) [0] 
21. Add polls (3/10) [0]
Additional features not on this list are also welcome.

Estimated delivery times
1/10 1 month
2/10 3 months
3/10 6 months
4/10 9 months
5/10 1 year
6/10 1.5 years
7/10 2 years
8/10 2.5 years
9/10 3 years
10/10 4 years

** Just like with any project, these numbers are probably optimistic. Multiply by 3 to get a more realistic estimate. **

>>1093628b-a3c2-45cb-ad9a-6005fda6d929
The problem is that if you use an encryption scheme that supports a hidden container, the powers that be will assume you did use it more often than not (although I admit it probably would be enough to subvert key disclosure law).
On the other hand, if you store stuff in the free space of a filesystem that doesn't support hidden containers by default (NTFS, for example) the possibility of any given person storing something in there vs just having run a scrubbing tool that overwrote the disk with random data is very low, especially if the tool doesn't become popular. Then the problem becomes bootstrapping the system, since you obviously can't just keep the code for the encryption program in plaintext or even in a reguarly encrypted disk. But you might be able to download it from a publicly accessible hidden service every time you boot your machine, for example. You can even boot your OS from such a hidden container if you use kexec or VMs, it would just require some initrd hacking and stuff.

>>28eb3e83-a347-4f4d-aa25-69b16bca9971
How do you think editing and deleting posts work? You can delete your own content from other people's clients by pushing an update of your data.json without the content you want gone. Of course this only works for content for which you have the private key (which basically means you are the author). For some reason when I was working on an update to the site to make it possible to post more file types (which is [here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HamXwKoauiykRmVLrQxDVjRGoVZX7ngkE/) btw), the content in my data.json was deleted and my client automatically signed the new version and pushed it to other clients, which accepted the new version.
